title: How to spell 'often'? Do you say 't' sound clearly, or do you just say something like 'ofn' - Quora

response.answer_text: How do you pronounce <often>? . Should it be pronounced as spelled? The spelling of English does not always have to have a strong connection to the way it is spoken. Part of the problem is that there are more phonemes to be represented than there are single letters to represent them. Written English is ambiguous. Reformers usually augment the alphabet with digraphs and diacritics. It is possibleto have more than enough symbols to represent the phonemes of speech. The phonemes of speech can be represented over a dozen different ways (on the average). Fortunately, about 4 ways is sufficient for 85% of the words in the dictionary. The answer to your question is usually found in a dictionary, pronunciation guide, or on-line dictionary. Very few spell /ˈɔfən/ in a way other than <often>. often remains the dominant or most common spelling. In American English, to preferred pronunciation is /ˈɔfən/. However, /ˈɔftən/ is an accepted variant pronunciation. Some speakers think they are obligated to pronounce words as they are spelled. They aren’t. OED: UK: ˈɒfn/, or /ˈɒftən/ . . . . US: /ˈɔːfn/, or /ˈɔːftən/

response.answer_text: I was brought up during a time when the ‘t’ was not pronounced. Since then, [I’m over 50] the pronunciation has returned in public speaking. Either way is OK, while I abhor changes to English that have no rational explanation, I prefer intelligent change. Next comes why we went from Pepeing, to Peking, to Beijing…all with no change [apparently] in China. Also, why we use a German pronunciation of the capital city of Russia, instead of the way Russians say it.
